natural problem: Seven sticks with lengths 2, 3, 5, 7, 11, 13 and 17 inches are placed in a box. Three of the sticks are randomly selected. What is the probability that a triangle can be formed by joining the endpoints of the sticks? Express your answer as a common fraction.
natural solution: By the triangle inequality, three segments form a triangle if and only if the sum of the smaller two lengths exceeds the greatest length.

Therefore, if $2$ is one of the sticks drawn, then the three sticks cannot be used to form a triangle. If 3 is the smallest length drawn, then the possible sets of sticks are (3,5,7) and (3,11,13). If 5 is the smallest length drawn, then (5,7,11), (5,11,13), and (5,13,17) are the sets that satisfy the triangle inequality.

If 7 is the smallest length drawn, then (7,11,13), (7,11,17), (7,13,17) all satisfy the triangle inequality. Finally, (11,13,17) satisfies the triangle inequality. In total, there are $2+3+3+1=9$ sets of sticks that could be used to form a triangle.
There are $\binom{7}{3}=35$ equally likely sets of 3 sticks, so the probability that one of the 9 sets that form a triangle will be chosen is $\boxed{\frac{9}{35}}$.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes sticks :: "int list" and triangles :: "int set"
assumes h0 : "sticks = [2, 3, 5, 7, 11, 13, 17]"
and h1 : "triangles = {a + b + c | a b c. a \<in> set sticks \<and> b \<in> set sticks \<and> c \<in> set sticks \<and> a \<noteq> b \<and> b \<noteq> c \<and> a \<noteq> c \<and> a + b > c \<and> a + c > b \<and> b + c > a}"
shows  "card triangles = 9" and "card (Pow (set sticks)) = 35" and "real (card triangles) / real (card (Pow (set sticks))) = 9 / 35"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Seven sticks with lengths 2, 3, 5, 7, 11, 13 and 17 inches are placed in a box. Three of the sticks are randomly selected. What is the probability that a triangle can be formed by joining the endpoints of the sticks? Express your answer as a common fraction. The final Answer is \frac{9}{35}
 ### Proof
 By the triangle inequality, three segments form a triangle if and only if the sum of the smaller two lengths exceeds the greatest length.
 Therefore, if $2$ is one of the sticks drawn, then the three sticks cannot be used to form a triangle. If 3 is the smallest length drawn, then the possible sets of sticks are (3,5,7) and (3,11,13). If 5 is the smallest length drawn, then (5,7,11), (5,11,13), and (5,13,17) are the sets that satisfy the triangle inequality.
 If 7 is the smallest length drawn, then (7,11,13), (7,11,17), (7,13,17) all satisfy the triangle inequality. Finally, (11,13,17) satisfies the triangle inequality. In total, there are $2+3+3+1=9$ sets of sticks that could be used to form a triangle.
 There are $\binom{7}{3}=35$ equally likely sets of 3 sticks, so the probability that one of the 9 sets that form a triangle will be chosen is $\boxed{\frac{9}{35}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes sticks :: "int list" and triangles :: "int set"
assumes h0 : "sticks = [2, 3, 5, 7, 11, 13, 17]"
and h1 : "triangles = {a + b + c | a b c. a \<in> set sticks \<and> b \<in> set sticks \<and> c \<in> set sticks \<and> a \<noteq> b \<and> b \<noteq> c \<and> a \<noteq> c \<and> a + b > c \<and> a + c > b \<and> b + c > a}"
shows  "card triangles = 9" and "card (Pow (set sticks)) = 35" and "real (card triangles) / real (card (Pow (set sticks))) = 9 / 35"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: You are given a list of sticks with lengths [2, 3, 5, 7, 11, 13, 17]. How many distinct triangles can be formed using any three of these sticks, such that the sum of the lengths of any two sides is greater than the length of the third side? What is the number of subsets of the given list of sticks? Finally, what is the ratio of the number of triangles to the number of subsets? The final answers are: 9 triangles can be formed, there are 35 subsets, and the ratio is 9/35.

a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Seven sticks with lengths 2, 3, 5, 7, 11, 13 and 17 inches are placed in a box. Three of the sticks are randomly selected. What is the probability that a triangle can be formed by joining the endpoints of the sticks? Express your answer as a common fraction. The final Answer is \frac{9}{35}
 ### Proof
 By the triangle inequality, three segments form a triangle if and only if the sum of the smaller two lengths exceeds the greatest length.
 Therefore, if $2$ is one of the sticks drawn, then the three sticks cannot be used to form a triangle. If 3 is the smallest length drawn, then the possible sets of sticks are (3,5,7) and (3,11,13). If 5 is the smallest length drawn, then (5,7,11), (5,11,13), and (5,13,17) are the sets that satisfy the triangle inequality.
 If 7 is the smallest length drawn, then (7,11,13), (7,11,17), (7,13,17) all satisfy the triangle inequality. Finally, (11,13,17) satisfies the triangle inequality. In total, there are $2+3+3+1=9$ sets of sticks that could be used to form a triangle.
 There are $\binom{7}{3}=35$ equally likely sets of 3 sticks, so the probability that one of the 9 sets that form a triangle will be chosen is $\boxed{\frac{9}{35}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes prob_triangle :: "real"
assumes h0 : "prob_triangle = (\<Sum> (a, b, c) \<in> {(2, 3, 5), (2, 3, 7), (2, 3, 11), (2, 3, 13), (2, 3, 17), (2, 5, 7), (2, 5, 11), (2, 5, 13), (2, 5, 17), (2, 7, 11), (2, 7, 13), (2, 7, 17), (2, 11, 13), (2, 11, 17), (2, 13, 17), (3, 5, 7), (3, 5, 11), (3, 5, 13), (3, 5, 17), (3, 7, 11), (3, 7, 13), (3, 7, 17), (3, 11, 13), (3, 11, 17), (3, 13, 17), (5, 7, 11), (5, 7, 13), (5, 7, 17), (5, 11, 13), (5, 11, 17), (5, 13, 17), (7, 11, 13), (7, 11, 17), (7, 13, 17), (11, 13, 17)}. card {x. triangle x})"
and h1 : "\<forall> (a, b, c). triangle (a, b, c) \<longleftrightarrow> a + b > c \<and> a + c > b \<and> b + c > a"
shows  "prob_triangle = 9 / 35"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: Find the probability that a randomly chosen combination of 3 sides from the set {2, 3, 5, 7, 11, 13, 17} forms a valid triangle. The final answer is $\frac{9}{35}$.

a_2.formal problem:
theorem
fixes triangle_probability :: "rat"
assumes h0 : "triangle_probability = (\<Sum> (i, j, k) | i \<in> {2, 3, 5, 7, 11, 13, 17} \<and> j \<in> {2, 3, 5, 7, 11, 13, 17} \<and> k \<in> {2, 3, 5, 7, 11, 13, 17} \<and> i \<noteq> j \<and> i \<noteq> k \<and> j \<noteq> k \<and> i + j > k \<and> i + k > j \<and> j + k > i. 1) / (\<Sum> (i, j, k) | i \<in> {2, 3, 5, 7, 11, 13, 17} \<and> j \<in> {2, 3, 5, 7, 11, 13, 17} \<and> k \<in> {2, 3, 5, 7, 11, 13, 17} \<and> i \<noteq> j \<and> i \<noteq> k \<and> j \<noteq> k. 1)"
shows  "triangle_probability = 9 / 35"
a_2.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Seven sticks with lengths 2, 3, 5, 7, 11, 13 and 17 inches are placed in a box. Three of the sticks are randomly selected. What is the probability that a triangle can be formed by joining the endpoints of the sticks? Express your answer as a common fraction. The final Answer is \frac{9}{35}
 ### Proof
 By the triangle inequality, three segments form a triangle if and only if the sum of the smaller two lengths exceeds the greatest length.
 Therefore, if $2$ is one of the sticks drawn, then the three sticks cannot be used to form a triangle. If 3 is the smallest length drawn, then the possible sets of sticks are (3,5,7) and (3,11,13). If 5 is the smallest length drawn, then (5,7,11), (5,11,13), and (5,13,17) are the sets that satisfy the triangle inequality.
 If 7 is the smallest length drawn, then (7,11,13), (7,11,17), (7,13,17) all satisfy the triangle inequality. Finally, (11,13,17) satisfies the triangle inequality. In total, there are $2+3+3+1=9$ sets of sticks that could be used to form a triangle.
 There are $\binom{7}{3}=35$ equally likely sets of 3 sticks, so the probability that one of the 9 sets that form a triangle will be chosen is $\boxed{\frac{9}{35}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes triangle_probability :: "rat"
assumes h0 : "triangle_probability = (\<Sum> (i, j, k) | i \<in> {2, 3, 5, 7, 11, 13, 17} \<and> j \<in> {2, 3, 5, 7, 11, 13, 17} \<and> k \<in> {2, 3, 5, 7, 11, 13, 17} \<and> i \<noteq> j \<and> i \<noteq> k \<and> j \<noteq> k \<and> i + j > k \<and> i + k > j \<and> j + k > i. 1) / (\<Sum> (i, j, k) | i \<in> {2, 3, 5, 7, 11, 13, 17} \<and> j \<in> {2, 3, 5, 7, 11, 13, 17} \<and> k \<in> {2, 3, 5, 7, 11, 13, 17} \<and> i \<noteq> j \<and> i \<noteq> k \<and> j \<noteq> k. 1)"
shows  "triangle_probability = 9 / 35"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_2.informal problem: What is the probability of forming a triangle by choosing three distinct prime numbers from the set {2, 3, 5, 7, 11, 13, 17} such that the sum of any two of these numbers is greater than the third number? The final answer is $\frac{9}{35}$.

a_3.formal problem:
theorem
fixes p :: real
assumes h0 : "p = (\<Sum> (i, j, k) | i \<noteq> j \<and> i \<noteq> k \<and> j \<noteq> k \<and> {2,3,5,7,11,13,17} = {i,j,k}. 1 / (card {(i, j, k). i < j \<and> j < k \<and> i + j > k \<and> {2,3,5,7,11,13,17} = {i,j,k}}))"
shows  "p = 9 / 35"

(* ### Problem

theorem
fixes p :: real
assumes h0 : "p = (\<Sum> (i, j, k) | i \<noteq> j \<and> i \<noteq> k \<and> j \<noteq> k \<and> {2,3,5,7,11,13,17} = {i,j,k}. 1 / (card {(i, j, k). i < j \<and> j < k \<and> i + j > k \<and> {2,3,5,7,11,13,17} = {i,j,k}}))"
shows  "p = 9 / 35"

a_3.informal problem: Given the set of prime numbers {2, 3, 5, 7, 11, 13, 17}, find the probability $p$ that if you randomly choose three distinct prime numbers from the set, the sum of any two of them is greater than the third one. The final answer is $\frac{9}{35}$.

a_4.formal problem:
theorem
fixes p :: real
assumes h0 : "p = 9 / 35"
shows  "p = (card {abc | abc. triangle abc \<and> abc \<subseteq> {2, 3, 5, 7, 11, 13, 17}}) / (card (combinations {2, 3, 5, 7, 11, 13, 17} 3))"

a_4.informal problem: In a set of prime numbers {2, 3, 5, 7, 11, 13, 17}, find the probability that a random combination of three numbers forms a triangle. The final answer is $\frac{9}{35}$.

a_5.formal problem:
theorem
fixes sticks :: "int list"
and triangle_count total_combinations :: int
assumes h0 : "sticks = [2, 3, 5, 7, 11, 13, 17]"
and h1 : "triangle_count = 9"
and h2 : "total_combinations = 35"
shows  "triangle_count / total_combinations = rat_of_int 9 / rat_of_int 35"
a_5.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Seven sticks with lengths 2, 3, 5, 7, 11, 13 and 17 inches are placed in a box. Three of the sticks are randomly selected. What is the probability that a triangle can be formed by joining the endpoints of the sticks? Express your answer as a common fraction. The final Answer is \frac{9}{35}
 ### Proof
 By the triangle inequality, three segments form a triangle if and only if the sum of the smaller two lengths exceeds the greatest length.
 Therefore, if $2$ is one of the sticks drawn, then the three sticks cannot be used to form a triangle. If 3 is the smallest length drawn, then the possible sets of sticks are (3,5,7) and (3,11,13). If 5 is the smallest length drawn, then (5,7,11), (5,11,13), and (5,13,17) are the sets that satisfy the triangle inequality.
 If 7 is the smallest length drawn, then (7,11,13), (7,11,17), (7,13,17) all satisfy the triangle inequality. Finally, (11,13,17) satisfies the triangle inequality. In total, there are $2+3+3+1=9$ sets of sticks that could be used to form a triangle.
 There are $\binom{7}{3}=35$ equally likely sets of 3 sticks, so the probability that one of the 9 sets that form a triangle will be chosen is $\boxed{\frac{9}{35}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes sticks :: "int list"
and triangle_count total_combinations :: int
assumes h0 : "sticks = [2, 3, 5, 7, 11, 13, 17]"
and h1 : "triangle_count = 9"
and h2 : "total_combinations = 35"
shows  "triangle_count / total_combinations = rat_of_int 9 / rat_of_int 35"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_5.informal problem: Given a list of sticks with lengths 2, 3, 5, 7, 11, 13, and 17, there are 9 possible triangles that can be formed. Out of a total of 35 combinations, what is the fraction of combinations that can form a triangle? The final answer is $\frac{9}{35}$.

a_6.formal problem:
theorem
fixes triangle_exists :: "int \<Rightarrow> int \<Rightarrow> int \<Rightarrow> bool"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> a b c. triangle_exists a b c = (a + b > c \<and> b + c > a \<and> c + a > b)"
and h1 : "let sticks = [2, 3, 5, 7, 11, 13, 17] in 
          card {(a, b, c) \<in> set sticks \<times> set sticks \<times> set sticks. 
          a \<noteq> b \<and> a \<noteq> c \<and> b \<noteq> c \<and> triangle_exists a b c} = 9"
shows  "9 / 35 = (9::real) / (35::real)"
a_6.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Seven sticks with lengths 2, 3, 5, 7, 11, 13 and 17 inches are placed in a box. Three of the sticks are randomly selected. What is the probability that a triangle can be formed by joining the endpoints of the sticks? Express your answer as a common fraction. The final Answer is \frac{9}{35}
 ### Proof
 By the triangle inequality, three segments form a triangle if and only if the sum of the smaller two lengths exceeds the greatest length.
 Therefore, if $2$ is one of the sticks drawn, then the three sticks cannot be used to form a triangle. If 3 is the smallest length drawn, then the possible sets of sticks are (3,5,7) and (3,11,13). If 5 is the smallest length drawn, then (5,7,11), (5,11,13), and (5,13,17) are the sets that satisfy the triangle inequality.
 If 7 is the smallest length drawn, then (7,11,13), (7,11,17), (7,13,17) all satisfy the triangle inequality. Finally, (11,13,17) satisfies the triangle inequality. In total, there are $2+3+3+1=9$ sets of sticks that could be used to form a triangle.
 There are $\binom{7}{3}=35$ equally likely sets of 3 sticks, so the probability that one of the 9 sets that form a triangle will be chosen is $\boxed{\frac{9}{35}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes triangle_exists :: "int \<Rightarrow> int \<Rightarrow> int \<Rightarrow> bool"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> a b c. triangle_exists a b c = (a + b > c \<and> b + c > a \<and> c + a > b)"
and h1 : "let sticks = [2, 3, 5, 7, 11, 13, 17] in 
          card {(a, b, c) \<in> set sticks \<times> set sticks \<times> set sticks. 
          a \<noteq> b \<and> a \<noteq> c \<and> b \<noteq> c \<and> triangle_exists a b c} = 9"
shows  "9 / 35 = (9::real) / (35::real)"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_6.informal problem: Given a set of sticks with lengths 2, 3, 5, 7, 11, 13, and 17, find the number of distinct triangles that can be formed using these sticks as sides. The final answer is 9 out of 35 possible combinations.

a_7.formal problem:
theorem
fixes a b c :: real
assumes h0 : "finite {2, 3, 5, 7, 11, 13, 17}"
and h1 : "card {2, 3, 5, 7, 11, 13, 17} = 7"
and h2 : "a \<in> {2, 3, 5, 7, 11, 13, 17} \<and> b \<in> {2, 3, 5, 7, 11, 13, 17} \<and> c \<in> {2, 3, 5, 7, 11, 13, 17} \<and> a \<noteq> b \<and> a \<noteq> c \<and> b \<noteq> c"
and h3 : "triangle a b c \<longleftrightarrow> a + b > c \<and> a + c > b \<and> b + c > a"
shows  "prob triangle = 9 / 35"

If 5 is the smallest length drawn, then (5,7,11), (5,11,13), and (5,13,17) are the sets that satisfy the triangle inequality.

theorem
fixes a b c :: real
assumes h0 : "finite {2, 3, 5, 7, 11, 13, 17}"
and h1 : "card {2, 3, 5, 7, 11, 13, 17} = 7"
and h2 : "a \<in> {2, 3, 5, 7, 11, 13, 17} \<and> b \<in> {2, 3, 5, 7, 11, 13, 17} \<and> c \<in> {2, 3, 5, 7, 11, 13, 17} \<and> a \<noteq> b \<and> a \<noteq> c \<and> b \<noteq> c"

a_7.informal problem: Among the first 7 prime numbers (2, 3, 5, 7, 11, 13, and 17), if you choose any 3 distinct numbers, what is the probability that the 3 numbers can form the sides of a triangle? The final answer is $\frac{9}{35}$.

a_8.formal problem:
theorem
fixes probability_triangle :: "int \<Rightarrow> int \<Rightarrow> int \<Rightarrow> rat"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>a b c. a + b > c \<and> a + c > b \<and> b + c > a \<longrightarrow> probability_triangle a b c = 1"
and h1 : "\<forall>a b c. \<not> (a + b > c \<and> a + c > b \<and> b + c > a) \<longrightarrow> probability_triangle a b c = 0"
and h2 : "{2, 3, 5, 7, 11, 13, 17}"
and h3 : "35"
shows  "(\<Sum>(a, b, c)\<in>(sticks \<times> sticks \<times> sticks). probability_triangle a b c) / total_selections = 9 / 35"

If 5 is the smallest length drawn, then (5,7,11), (5,11,13), and (5,13,17) are the sets that satisfy the triangle inequality.

 *)

theorem
fixes probability_triangle :: "int \<Rightarrow> int \<Rightarrow> int \<Rightarrow> rat"

and h1 : "\<forall>a b c. \<not> (a + b > c \<and> a + c > b \<and> b + c > a) \<longrightarrow> probability_triangle a b c = 0"

a_8.informal problem: Given a set of sticks with lengths {2, 3, 5, 7, 11, 13, 17}, find the probability of selecting three sticks such that they form a triangle. The probability is 9/35.

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes p :: real
assumes h0 : "p = 9 / 35"
shows  "p = (\<Sum>(x, y, z) | distinct [x, y, z] \<and> (x + y > z) \<and> (x + z > y) \<and> (y + z > x) \<and> {x, y, z} \<subseteq> {2, 3, 5, 7, 11, 13, 17}. 1) / (\<Sum>(x, y, z) | distinct [x, y, z] \<and> {x, y, z} \<subseteq> {2, 3, 5, 7, 11, 13, 17}. 1)"

  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem: Given a set of prime numbers {2, 3, 5, 7, 11, 13, 17}, find the probability that three distinct numbers are chosen from this set such that they form the sides of a triangle (i.e., the sum of any two sides is greater than the third side). The final answer is $\frac{9}{35}$.
